explanation:
Agent A is correct for the configuration they describe. If mhd_assert is defined as
  #define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
then the source statement
  mhd_assert (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != fd);
preprocesses to the no-op expression-statement ((void)0);. That statement has no effect at runtime and removing it would not change program behaviour in that build configuration, which matches the MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 definition of dead code (an executed operation whose removal does not affect behaviour). 

Notes/nuance: This conclusion is configuration-dependent. If the project is built with an mhd_assert that performs checks (i.e. not defined to ((void)0)), the assertion is not dead. The rule applies to the project as built; in the shown configuration (mhd_assert a no-op) the report is correct. The failing test compile is orthogonal — it doesn't change the semantic point that an assertion macro expanded to ((void)0) produces a no-effect statement that meets the definition of dead code in Rule 2.2.
